docs.abstract: With state legislatures passing new abortion restrictions, the Mississippi Reproductive Freedom Fund follows its own compass on how to best help clients.
docs.snippet: With state legislatures passing new abortion restrictions, the Mississippi Reproductive Freedom Fund follows its own compass on how to best help clients.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Brandy found out she was pregnant for the fifth time, she was 25 and single and had given birth to her third child two months earlier. Soon after that, she lost her retail management job of six years. It was midwinter 2013, and she could barely pay her heating bill. “I knew I wasn’t going to keep it if I could do anything about it,” she says now of the pregnancy. A month later, once she could afford the cab fare, she called a taxi to drive her 20 minutes to Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the only abortion clinic in Mississippi.

headline.main: What Abortion Access Looks Like in Mississippi: One Person at a Time

docs.abstract: Ankle bracelets are promoted as a humane alternative to jail. But private companies charge defendants hundreds of dollars a month to wear the surveillance devices. If people can’t pay, they may end up behind bars.
docs.snippet: Ankle bracelets are promoted as a humane alternative to jail. But private companies charge defendants hundreds of dollars a month to wear the surveillance devices. If people can’t pay, they may end up behind bars.
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is a collaboration between the Times and ProPublica, the independent nonprofit investigative-journalism organization.

headline.main: Digital Jail: How Electronic Monitoring Drives Defendants Into Debt

docs.abstract: This gently ironic self-assessment not only pays tribute to the luck that has propelled him through life but also eulogizes a loved one less fortunate — that ghost from his youth.
docs.snippet: This gently ironic self-assessment not only pays tribute to the luck that has propelled him through life but also eulogizes a loved one less fortunate — that ghost from his youth.
docs.lead_paragraph: At first, the ghost prompting this anthem to middle age appears as both an ancestral spirit and the specter of mortality. Chaun Ballard builds his bluesy genealogy with metonymy and synecdoche, from squeaking shoes and Polaroids to neckties and healthy diets. Even though our speaker has joined the ranks of adults, he continues to appreciate the bounty that has shaped his cultural inheritance. In the end, this gently ironic self-assessment not only pays tribute to the luck that has propelled him through life but also eulogizes a loved one less fortunate — that ghost from his youth. Selected by Rita Dove

byline.original: By Chaun Ballard and Rita Dove

docs.abstract: The young woman was extremely mindful of her allergy. Yet her body started having these terrible reactions.
docs.snippet: The young woman was extremely mindful of her allergy. Yet her body started having these terrible reactions.
docs.lead_paragraph: ‘‘Call 911,” the 21-year-old woman gasped to her older sister. “I’m having an attack.” The older sister looked over at the young woman. She looked scared, a thin layer of sweat glistening on her pale face. The older sister immediately picked up the phone and dialed. She’d heard about her sister’s strange attacks but had never seen one. Her younger sister had come to her bedroom earlier that evening, saying that the inside of her mouth was itchy and that she was worried this was an allergic reaction. She didn’t want to be alone, in case the two doses of Benadryl she’d already taken weren’t enough.

headline.main: She Wasn’t Exposed to Nuts. Why Was She Going Into Anaphylactic Shock?
headline.print_headline: She Wasn’t Exposed to Nuts. Why Was She Going Into Anaphylactic Shock?

docs.abstract: Images of brutality should do more than provide a quick emotional fix. They should indict the viewer.
docs.snippet: Images of brutality should do more than provide a quick emotional fix. They should indict the viewer.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, June 25, Rosa Ramírez was filmed at home in San Martín, El Salvador. Ramírez stands by a doorway in a small interior. She is distraught, and her large brown eyes glisten in the glare of camera lights.

headline.main: A Crime Scene at the Border

docs.abstract: Cover the nostril closest to the floor and breathe into the other one. Have a partner perform 80 to 120 chest compressions per minute.
docs.snippet: Cover the nostril closest to the floor and breathe into the other one. Have a partner perform 80 to 120 chest compressions per minute.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Is the horse breathing, and does it have a heartbeat?” Start with these questions, says Laura Javsicas, an equine veterinarian who has performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation on dozens of newborn foals. If everything goes right, a foal emerges from its mother front hooves first, head tucked like that of a diver. But four gangly legs can cause things to go awry. Foals born by cesarean section can be particularly at risk of needing CPR.

headline.main: How to Do CPR on a Foal
headline.print_headline: How to Do CPR On a Foal

docs.abstract: The older man was unsteady on his feet and seemed to be talking nonstop. Then the seizures started, and his wife sounded the alarm.
docs.snippet: The older man was unsteady on his feet and seemed to be talking nonstop. Then the seizures started, and his wife sounded the alarm.
docs.lead_paragraph: “It’s my husband, isn’t it?” the woman asked the volunteer emergency medical worker directing traffic away from the restaurant where she was supposed to meet her spouse, who was then 71. The volunteer nodded grimly. She knew most of the emergency workers; her husband still volunteered with them. The wife hurried into the restaurant. When she made her way through the door, she saw him sprawled on the floor. His eyes were open but unfocused. His pants were soaked with urine.

headline.main: The Man’s Blood Pressure Dropped, and He Was Acting Strange. What Was Going On?

docs.abstract: Does it make sense, medically or ethically, when fertility clinics refuse to treat prospective mothers they consider too large?
docs.snippet: Does it make sense, medically or ethically, when fertility clinics refuse to treat prospective mothers they consider too large?
docs.lead_paragraph: The first time a doctor told Gina Balzano that she was too fat to have a baby was in 2013. She was 32, weighed 317 pounds and had been trying to get pregnant since soon after she and her husband, Nick, married in 2010. Balzano — whom I have known since high school — lives in Waltham, Mass., and works in special education. She’s the kind of person whom others often go to with their problems, but her own predicament, after three years of negative pregnancy tests, had left her feeling overwhelmed. “I’ve always had horrible, heavy, painful periods, so I thought something was wrong,” she says. “But I didn’t know enough to know what to worry about.” She told herself it was time to find out.

headline.main: When You’re Told You’re Too Fat to Get Pregnant

docs.abstract: President Trump’s election made the Murdoch family more powerful than ever. But the bitter struggle between James and Lachlan threatened to tear the company apart.
